Regardless of whether you're new to what was formerly known as Yakuza and is now known under it's more literal translation, Like a Dragon, or someone that has played the entire series, this game comes highly recommended, even more so if you love epic stories, awesome characters and character development, and/or are a fan of RPG's. Bonus points if don't mind having yourself a nice cry because a game's story got to you.

Story and Character Development (A+ or 100/100): Even if you're new to the series (as I was when I played this the first time) and some of the nods to the series' history will not hit as hard as they otherwise would have, I still thought the story was amazing Those nods will hit even harder if you have played the rest of the series and are still somehow in the dark about what awaits you. 

This was the first game I played in the series when I first played it a couple years ago, and it connected with me so much that I spent the next year playing the rest of the series before playing Infinite Wealth (the sequel to this game). Story and character development are where this series shines most.

Combat and Systems (for RPG fans A or 90/100, for most other people B or 80/100): If you love RPG's, I think you will find the combat enjoyable even if it does not do much to add anything new to the genre. I really enjoyed it myself, but it is not as if it does a lot to avoid feeling repetitive at times. Still, it was the first RPG game in the series and it does nearly everything else well. Good build variety, enjoyable skills, upgrades to chase, paths to making your characters very OP while still ensuring the game still feels balanced.

Side Content (B or 85/100): While the "weird" and "cringe" sub-stories are even more weird and cringe relative to the earlier games, I do not think it is so great that it justifies the narrative that the series has abandoned its identity. Some are weird, some are cringe, some are funny, and some are even touching. That has always been a constant in these games.

The side activity for making money is ok, but is not as engaging as some of activities in prior games (fellas, it's ok, we know you spent hours giving a hostess a makeover in the hostess club activity in prior games). There are some other activities new the series that were challenging and enjoyable enough to complete all of the challenges and content tied to them.

Voice Acting (A+ or 10/10): When I first played this a couple of years ago, I did not understand that this was the first game in the series to receive English dubs. Having said that, I now try to play each game where there are English dubs twice (once with the Japanese VA's and the other with the English VA's) because of how much I enjoy the Japanese VA's as an English speaking person. 

It was always going to be difficult for them to follow in the footsteps of the performances from earlier games in the series, but as an English speaking person, I gauge that quality as "can I still understand the emotional meaning or heaviness of how the character they are portraying is feeling even if I do not speak the language?" and the answer here is a resounding yes.

While I'm not sure I have enjoyed the English VA's in remakes being made of earlier games (or Man Who Erased His Name and Pirate Yakuza), I do think the English voice cast does an amazing job here.

Overall (A or 95/100): One of my top 3 games in the series and one of my all time favorite stories.

The story itself is quite good. It starts off strong, slows down a bit in the middle, but finishes with a powerful and satisfying ending. One aspect that really appealed to me is that most of the main characters are people in their 30s and 40s. That alone makes them feel far more relatable and human compared to the typical ‚Äúcolored-hair hero #392 with cute sidekick #292‚Äù trope so common in JRPGs.

While the game is filled with slapstick humor, the main story maintains a serious tone. By the end, I genuinely cared about most of the main characters‚Äîthough, unfortunately, some of the party members who join later aren‚Äôt as well developed. Story-wise, it‚Äôs easily above average compared to most games released today.

Now, the reason I call it a flawed gem lies in the gameplay. At first, I enjoyed it, but over time the gameplay began to feel repetitive. Since the game is heavily story-driven, the developers padded it with a lot of side content‚Äîmini-games, item collecting, crafting, plant growing, optional dungeons, and even a kart racing mode. Those are fantastic if you enjoy a ‚Äúplayground‚Äù approach to your games, and if you dive into everything, you‚Äôll easily get hundreds of hours and your money worth out of it. But for me, I was mostly in it for the story and scenery. Some sections ended up feeling like chores, especially since the difficulty curve isn‚Äôt consistent. The game is about 95% easy battles, then suddenly it throws a few boss fights at you that require grinding for hours to level up, gather items, and fine-tune your party.

All in all, I appreciated that this game feels made with adult players as it deals with mature themes and depicts the nightlife of a major city without crossing into crass sexualization, excessive gore, or cheap fanservice. This game was recommended to me and purchased for me by a friend. This game - the seventh in the series - is often mentioned as a good entry-point to the massive Yakuza franchise, and I don't have reason to disagree.

Being my first entry into the franchise, I don't have much knowledge of the world or narrative. Based on the name, marketing and reputation for this game, I formed a misconception that this would be some kind of wacky romp of a story, a-la the later 'Saints Row' games, so I was surprised to instead receive a straight-edged drama full of serious character and passion. The silly-ness is there, don't get me wrong, but it shows itself in the side-stories, random encounters and minigames rather than in the forefront of the game as a whole.

Once I adjusted to the tone of the story, I then tricked myself for a second time by assuming that I would be involving myself in the creation or development of an underworld organisation or crime family, so you can imagine my surprise when I got to the end of the story and was still essentially homeless - fighting men dressed in garbage bags in the sewers, and searching for cockroaches in the park - almost a side-character in the wider world of the existing yakuza organisations. Cameos and references to other games in the series are evident, even though most of them certainly flew over my head - a swelling orchestral score and a dramatic zoom-in and reveal as a new Japanese man walks into a room gives it away! Saying that, the new protagonist and independent story don't rely on prior franchise knowledge.

I did go through the game using the English dub - I hear that the earlier games in the franchise don't have great voice acting outside of the Japanese originals, but I agree with the general sentiment that the English performances in this rendition are very well done in most instances. The numerous jokes, puns, and creative NPC names that would obviously not be direct translations show a level of care far beyond a simple copy-paste translate job that many C- or J-RPGs rely on.

On the topic of care, I find the world- and level-designs to have been very well crafted. Based on real Japanese prefectures, the playable spaces are very densely detailed with minimal repetition, and the NPCs and vehicles populating and moving around the environment give it a somewhat genuine feel. I did get slightly annoyed by the distribution of a set of collectibles halfway through the game, forcing me to re-explore many of the nooks and crannies that I had already delved through.

Overall, the game seems to be well made, and runs very well. In my time I only experienced one or two noticeable bugs. If you pay too close attention, you may wish for more variety in some character animations - such as the slow bow-legged walk that everyone in Japan seems to do.

Settle down for some long gameplay sessions. This game includes both long sections of game where Saving is disabled, as well as hour-long cutscenes without warning (or twenty minute cutscenes with one minute of gameplay leading into another twenty minute cutscene). For some reason, there seems to be two or three different levels of production of cutscenes, so halfway through a scene the quality will suddenly lower, or the audio and animation will stop and suddenly the characters are speaking to eachother with freeze frames and text boxes - perhaps a decision to reduce the translation work or an otherwise creative choice, but it feels quite jarring and doesn't seem to align with the high production values of the rest of the story.

The turn-based fights are fine, but I find myself annoyed by several implemented mechanics. The free 'follow-up' attacks that your party perform outside of your control may do additional damage, but also remove certain status effects from enemies or attract aggro in a way that could be detrimental to the fight. There are a large number of environmental interactions that can occur during fights, such as your character kicking a bin, sign, or bicycle towards an enemy, but more often than not the object misses the enemy or instead hits an ally. You have no control of the movement or positioning of the characters in the fight, making it very difficult to target group- or area- attacks, and have no way to manoeuvre away from similar attacks on your own party. I'm currently grinding towards the post-game battle dungeon 'True Final Millennium Tower', and have found myself up to this point primarily only using basic attacks, although the grinding and levelling system is encouraging me to experiment with different classes and party-formats that I didn't need to change during the story.

Overall, a well made game with a long but engaging story. A good springboard into the franchise, but not the greatest battle mechanics. Not for everyone, but recommended if interested.

## Why

- Absurdly over the top, but can still get you invested in characters
- You never know what you're gonna get when you start a side quest
- Entertaining JRPG combat with depth and real-time elements
- Ichiban is strong candidate for my number one protagonist

## Why Not

- Gets a bit grindier toward the end after mostly avoiding it well
- Some late game bosses are absolute tanks even if you're levelled appropriately

## Impressions

Trying to predict where Like a Dragon will go next is an exercise in futility. The prologue introduces us to Ichiban, our baseball bat-wielding golden retriever of a protagonist, by having him utterly fail to meet his shakedown quota for the day by helping his intended victims instead. After setting the scene with numerous, extensive cutscenes, the game spares itself constantly trying to justify Ichiban's continued existence as a yakuza by having him take the fall for a senpai and spending 18 years in jail.

Upon release he finds a world entirely unlike the one he left. The clan he used to belong to effectively no longer exists, seemingly betrayed by Ichiban's father figure who's now a prominent figure in the rival clan. In classic Ichiban fashion he immediately makes a beeline for said father-figure, determined to prove he's actually a good guy despite all evidence to the contrary, and catches a bullet for his trouble. Waking up some time later in a homeless encampment he meets the first member of his party, and thus begins his heroic journey!

I really enjoy how much the devs leaned into the switch from beat-em-up to JRPG; it's even given an in-universe justification via Ichiban being a huge Dragon Quest fan and the combat encounters just being his interpretation of fights through that lens. All the classic elements are here; physical attacks, magic with elemental types, gear and classes, but they're all reinterpreted for a modern setting (e.g you gain access to the job system by going to 'Hello Work' and... looking for a job). There's also a bit of added interactivity during the turn based combat; well timed inputs on attacks and blocks will give you bonues damage/negation. This interactivity with the absolutely wild animations for some attacks and creative enemy design keep combat intersting throughout a long, soap opera style story.

The story definitely works best if you just let yourself be caught up in it without thinking too hard about how/why any of this is happening, though despite its frequent absurdity there are a lot of really touching moments and compelling characters scattered about. Ichiban himself is probably the best of these; his irrepressible optimism and faith along with a... straightforward approach to decision-making make him a force to be reckoned with. He's not naive, he's been around the block and knows how the world works, but he chooses to believe the best of people even if it seems ridiculous. And well, if they don't live up to those expectations, there's always his trusty baseball bat. Your party members all have their own stories as well, especially the core 3. You'll meet some others as the story progresses who are fleshed out to varying degrees, and they're different enough that most players will find at least someone to get attached to.

I'd heard Yakuza side stories were something else, and they definitely lived up to that. The variety in both mechanics and tone is crazy, ranging from helping a little girl collect donations for her sick brother to changing lives with the power of ultra-spicy kimchi and funding the development of a gigantic Roomba (then naturally having to fight it after it turns evil). Each time you reach into the side-story lucky dip you'll find something new, and I definitely went out of my way whenever I saw a new marker pop up just to see what craziness was in store for me next.

I don't know if I'll ever go back to play the (6!) original games in the series, but I'm definitely on the Like a Dragon train going forward. This game wore a lot of hats and pulled them all off with style, keeping me engaged over a ~60 hour runtime and making me hungry for Infinite Wealth to go on sale so I can see where the ‰∏ÄÁï™ protagonist and (hopefully) friends go from here. You're missing out if you don't give this one a try, especially on sale for ~$8.

[i]Yakuza: Like a Dragon[/i] is not just a new chapter in the Yakuza series ‚Äî it‚Äôs a rebirth. It takes massive creative risks by shifting from real-time brawling to turn-based RPG combat, introducing an entirely new protagonist, and building a story around a fresh cast. And somehow, it succeeds beyond expectations. What emerges is one of the most heartfelt, ambitious, and emotionally powerful RPGs of the past decade.

Ichiban Kasuga is a revelation. He‚Äôs not Kiryu‚Äôs replacement ‚Äî he‚Äôs his own kind of hero. Where Kiryu is stoic, composed, and controlled, Ichiban is wild, passionate, goofy, impulsive, and endlessly optimistic. Left behind by the people he devoted his life to, betrayed by the system he believed in, and thrown into a world that forgot him, Ichiban chooses not bitterness but hope. His compassion and refusal to give up make him instantly lovable ‚Äî a hero who leads not through fear, but through loyalty and kindness.

The story balances heavy themes and absurd humor with incredible precision. Homelessness, political corruption, human trafficking, organized crime ‚Äî the game isn‚Äôt afraid to explore harsh social realities, but it never crushes the player under their weight. The emotional journey is cathartic and inspiring, and when the big moments hit, they hit hard. The bond between Ichiban and his party ‚Äî Adachi, Nanba, Saeko, Joon-gi Han, Zhao, and others ‚Äî becomes the beating heart of the game. They aren‚Äôt just allies; they‚Äôre found family.

The shift to turn-based combat is brilliant. Every skill feels impactful, stylish, and hilarious, blending JRPG strategy with the absurd comedy the series is famous for. Classes (or ‚Äújobs‚Äù) like Hero, Hostess, Breakdancer, Chef, and Musician are ridiculous in concept but shockingly deep in mechanics. Planning buffs, debuffs, status effects, and combos turns every encounter into a satisfying strategic puzzle. Summons ‚Äî or ‚ÄúPoundmates‚Äù ‚Äî are some of the funniest and most creative attacks ever seen in the genre.

Yokohama is stunning ‚Äî massive, vibrant, and alive. It is easily one of the richest open worlds in the franchise, full of side quests that range from laugh-out-loud comedy to genuinely emotional character stories. You can feed hungry cats, help struggling businesses, fight street gangs, mentor employees, audition theater actors, drink with party members, or bully seasoned criminals at karaoke. The world constantly rewards curiosity.

Side content is huge and diverse:
‚Ä¢ Dragon Kart racing
‚Ä¢ Restaurant bonding & personality stats
‚Ä¢ Can collecting mini-game
‚Ä¢ Business management simulation (one of the best in the whole series)
‚Ä¢ Underground arena challenges
‚Ä¢ Vocational exam quizzes
‚Ä¢ Dating routes and party bonds

Every mode is polished, meaningful, and entertaining ‚Äî nothing feels like filler.

Visually, [i]Like a Dragon[/i] is dramatic and expressive. Character performances are top-tier, cutscenes are cinematic and emotionally charged, and the soundtrack is spectacular ‚Äî blending dramatic orchestral pieces, triumphant battle anthems, and soulful emotional tracks. The final chapter, the music that accompanies it, and the ending cutscenes combine into one of the most unforgettable finales in modern RPG storytelling.

[i]Yakuza: Like a Dragon[/i] isn‚Äôt simply a new direction ‚Äî it‚Äôs proof that change can build legacy rather than erase it. It honors everything the series represents: loyalty, sacrifice, brotherhood, justice, humor, and heart. I want to like this game, but I can't.
I like turn-based combat and wanted to try a yakuza game, so I got it on sale.

The main characters are great. 
Cool gameplay concepts.

But, after a while, it just stops being fun.
Side quests bored me to no end, the main story had good moments, but nothing to keep me that much invested. 
The absurd attacks stopped making me laugh. The JRPG parody become just become the worst parts of an JRPG : long, grindy, lots of mechanics unused as the difficulty curve mostly* looks like a flatline.
Combat is boring. You'll overpower most enemies after a certain point, so I stopped trying to improve my strategies, gear, etc...
And then, the [spoiler] Majima & Saejima [/spoiler] fight. Suddenly, a mandatory boss fight has 10 more levels than you. Cool. And you simply lose. Now the game wants to be difficult.
Before that, you unlock an area for grinding. I choosed to quit.

I don't think this game is worth it.
Honestly, I would love to be proven wrong. Maybe I didn't understand some mechanics. But I don't want to trust another promise of 'it gets fun after X hours".
